question: Write a diary entry as the Parrot, describing your life with your mistress, the farewell, and being snatched away, while referencing the trouble caused to her lover.
gold_answer: Diary Entry — My days with my mistress were filled with warmth and chatter. Today, I said farewell to Corinna, her eyes glistening with sorrow. I was snatched away by envy, separated from her gentle hands. I have heard it said that my mistress is born to be a cause of trouble to her lover, and perhaps, even my loss plays a part in the tangled affairs of the heart.
llm_answer:
Diary of the Parrot

Day I know not, for the sun has set on my voice for ever.

I was the pride of her bower, my feathers greener than the emerald, my beak a blush of saffron.  From the moment I was given, I pleased my mistress; I lived to please her.  I mimicked every sound—her laughter, her sighs, the lover’s whispered vows—so prettily that my lisping notes became the music of the house.  A nut, a drop of water, a poppy for sleep: with these I was content, for I had her smiles.

But my chatter, once a delight, became the scourge of her lover.  When he beat her, I repeated his own cruel words back to him; when he swore fidelity, I piped the names of other women I had heard in the streets.  My beak was quicker than his conscience, and he grew to hate me.  Yet I feared no revenge: I was a lover of peaceful concord, guilty of no wars.

On the seventh day the North wind carried her prayers across the seas, but Destiny stood spinning her thread.  My tongue, still crying “Corinna, farewell!” faltered only when the dark closed round me.  Snatched away by envious hands—whose I cannot tell—I felt the last flutter of my wings beat against the cage of night.

Now, in the Elysian grove where innocent birds range, I attract the guiltless swans and Juno’s peacock with the memory of my human voice.  My small tomb bears the truth: “From this very tomb I may be judged to have been the favorite of my mistress.  I had a tongue more skilled at talking than other birds.”  Yet even here I wonder: did my mocking echo hasten the blow that bruised her cheek?  If so, let this stone weigh lighter, for I loved her more than speech.

scores.explanation: The Model Answer captures the essence of the Gold Answer, elaborating on the parrot's life with its mistress, the farewell, and its snatching away, while also referencing the trouble caused to her lover. The additional details about the parrot's mimicry, its contentment, and its reflections in the Elysian grove are consistent with the Retrieved Context and enrich the narrative without deviating from the core truth. All key facts from the Gold Answer are included, and the answer is fully grounded in the provided context.
